The “Ways of Working” document provides an overview of how members of
For information about the members involved in the governance, including the Project Delivery Team, please refer to the documentation on

This document offers high-level information on communication, community structures, and project management processes.
For details, please refer to the Foreword, Afterword, and Community Handbook within
Below we have listed all communication channels used in

.
For details, please refer to the
You can reach out to all members listed in our
by tagging them on GitHub issues or Pull Requests, or directly on
, which are great places to discuss ideas for new contributions and to get started with making them.
Talks, presentations and recordings from different events are posted on our
Hosted all throughout the year, our recurring community calls are important and engaging spaces where you can participate in

Some require signing up (📝) and some don’t (✅).
All members are welcome to join these calls! ✨

: These are online coworking spaces for everyone, hosted fortnightly from 15:00 to 17:00 UK time. Here you can meet others from the community, do some focused co-writing, or catch up with the Working Groups (
: These calls are hosted every two months by the project delivery team to share governance-related updates with the community.
: These calls are hosted every two months by the community management WG to onboard new members of the community in the project (

members collaborate with different communities to co-design and co-host Fireside Chat events that are informal yet structured discussions on topics of shared interests across research/data science communities (

: Every second Wednesday at 14:30 UK time, members of the Translation and Localisation Working Groups share this coworking space to carry out translation work across several languages, and support each other (
: Every second Tuesday of the month, at 16:00 UK time, members of the Infrastructure Working Groups work together on infrastructure-related maintenance and development efforts (
s: Every second Monday of the month, at 17:00 UK time, members of the Accessibility Working Group work together on access-related chapters and guidance for the community (

: These bi-yearly online or hybrid events are hosted by the Book Dash Working Group. These are less intense versions of Book Sprint, inviting members through an application-based selection process to work on specific areas of the book and/or community initiatives (
: Every Monday, from 11:00 to 12:00 UK time, the project delivery team and members from across different Working Groups use these coworking calls to catch up on their task lists (
: These meetings will be organised on a monthly basis for the members working together at the Constitutional Level. Dates and times will be decided with the members of the Steering Committee.
All members, especially at the maintenance and constitution levels, commit to:
making the implicit explicit by documenting their work
abiding by the Code of Conduct in all community platforms and spaces where they represent
following the contribution guidelines and keeping them up to date
recording any new updates, exceptions or useful knowledge in project management and core documents needed to facilitate collaboration
dedicating their time and expertise to fixing open issues either directly via GitHub or providing mentorship and support to community members and project contributors
feedback on issues in open source software used throughout
GitHub repo or other open source projects where this issue can be fixed
Document and share any conversation from closed spaces (such as email, Slack, or 1:1 meeting) in a GitHub issue that could be useful for the community or community members in enabling their work in

All members help triage open issues, review Pull Requests or address any questions raised on GitHub asynchronously.
As most members do not work full time on
, it might take some time until your query or contribution is addressed - especially if expert knowledge is needed. Don’t be afraid to nudge if they’ve not replied after a few days! :sparkling_heart:
All members, especially at the maintenance and constitution levels, will:
monitor open issues and Pull Requests on the project’s GitHub repository to identify if feedback, comments or connections can help address any concern or build on any suggested ideas/features.
whenever possible, post about the issues and Pull Requests in public forums (newsletter, Slack, Twitter) to facilitate participation from new members in the community.

review or assign a reviewer to open Pull Requests for review. This should be taken as an opportunity to connect contributors with specific interests, availability or technical skills that could be useful for the ongoing work.
connect issues and Pull Requests where possible (for example, by mentioning ‘Fixes #[issue number]’ in the Pull Request description). By adding “closes #issue” or
in a comment on a pull request, merging the pull request will close the issue automatically.
once completed, approve Pull Requests (for the contributors to merge them) and/or close issues immediately (if not linked to specific Pull Request) with a comment describing how it was addressed.

when reviewing a pull request or commenting on issues, be specific, describe your ideas clearly, comment to request changes or make a pull request to the file that should be merged (please do not use the “request changes” option when reviewing Pull Requests).
use your interactions on GitHub or other community spaces to provide support, mentorship and acknowledgement to our community of contributors.

children.label: Authorship and Contributorship in The Turing Way

children.value: Anyone who contributes to the book is considered an author of
Our Community Handbook provides detailed processes and guidelines for

.
This section offers an overview and highlights the main points to ensure you have an initial understanding.

You don’t have to have written a chapter to be listed as an author.
Substantial contributions to the running of the project, for example, adding in (or improving) documentation on
, hosted an event, given a talk or onboarded new members to
, all count as core contributions warranting authorship.
Contributing small amounts over a long time, and thinking about the strategy for the project also count for authorship.
(listed above) which always renders to the latest release.
We release a new version every 6 months or if substantial updates to existing chapters are made, such as after Book Dash events.

Authorship is cumulative.
If you have been added as an author on one release, you will stay as an author on all future releases.
Thank you for contributing to the Turing Way!
We value your thoughtful participation and contributions to
